sec.title: Context:
sec.p: During ongoing passive surveillance in Burail, Chandigarh an unexpected rise in number of acute viral hepatitis (AVH) was reported during December 2016.

sec.title: Aims:
sec.p: An outbreak of AVH was investigated in an urbanized village, Burail, in Chandigarh, India with an objective of describing its epidemiological features.

sec.title: Settings and Design:
sec.p: A house-to-house survey was conducted in Burail (population 51,958).

sec.title: Subjects and Methods:
sec.p: WHO's standard case definition for AVH was used to identify cases. Suspected cases were tested for hepatitis A virus (HAV) and E virus (HEV) using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. Drinking water samples were tested for fecal contamination. Control measures were implemented to contain the outbreak.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis Used:
sec.p: Descriptive analysis was done as per time, person, and place.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Out of 141 confirmed cases of AVH, 85.1% were positive for HEV, 12.8% for HAV, and 2.1% for both HAV and HEV. The attack rate was 27.1 per 10,000 in a population. Males were affected more than females ( P < 0.05). One of the areas reported a leakage in drinking water pipeline and had highest attack rate (36.8/10000 population). Drinking water samples were found negative for contamination. Around 27% of confirmed cases reported history of taking food from local vendors in Burail 2â€“6 weeks prior to the onset of symptoms.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: This study described the epidemiological features of dual hepatitis outbreak due to HAV and HEV from Chandigarh, Union Territory, north India.
